subject: Re: [junit] understanding junit
msgSnippet: At 09:52 AM 20/02/02, you wrote: 1. It seems all the method names should start with test . Can the method name be testX, where X can be anything? or X
messageBody:
At 09:52 AM 20/02/02, you wrote:
1. It seems all the method names should start with
"test". Can the method name be testX, where X can be
anything? or X necessarily has to be a method of my
class being tested.


X can be anything. I usually use something like

in the class to be tested:
String foo(Object in1, Object in2){...}


in the test class:
public void testFooNormalInputs() {}
public void testFooIn1Null() {}
public void testFooIn2Null() {}
public void testFooBothInputsNull() {}
etc.

Some people combine these into one method. That's more a matter of style
than anything else. (Some of us have it, and some... ;)




2. It is not uncommon that the methods of a class
require a 'state' in order for them to be called.
and coming to this 'state' is often not an easy task.
Is the method setUp meant for this purpose? But
then, different methods require a different setup.
What does junit framework suggest on this issue of
having setUps and tearDowns for each method?

setUp is guaranteed to be called before each and every test, with tearDown
called after. The usual thing I do is set up a test instance of the object
in setUp, and set it to null in tearDown. (This doesn't always work, for
example in testing singletons.) Further setup to reach the state ready for
testing would be done in the test method.

For example:
public class Bar {
public Bar(int importantValue) { ... }

public void setImportantValue(int newValue) { ... }
public String foo(Object o1, Object o2) { ... }
}

in the test class:

private Bar bar;

protected void setUp() {
bar = new Bar(1);
}

public void testFooNormalValues() {
// we know that bar here is clean and fresh:
assertEquals("foo!", bar.foo(new Object(), new Object()));
}

public void testFooNullValues() {
// still fresh here:
assertEquals("Oof!", bar.foo(null, null));
}

public void testFooNegativeImportantValue() {
// fresh, but not as fresh as we want it:
bar.setImportantValue(-1);
assertEquals("Oof!", bar.foo(null, null));
}

The setUp method is more for convenience that anything else: you don't have
to type in/cut 'n paste the set up code for your test object in all the
test methods. There's nothing to stop you from doing so, however, and in
some cases you may need to: for example if you're testing the constructor.



3. I do not really think I have understood what
junit is. Is the junit framework a spec? Does this
really require a seperate software? I mean, calling
a sequence of methods of a class is not that non-
trivial. Can somebody explain to me why I should use
junit?

JUnit helps to test methods, and the state of the tested object after...
When you have to test a sequence of methods you're moving into functional
testing - though the boundary is by no means clearly defined.
That said, to test a sequence of methods:
1. Test the individual methods
2. Test the sequence
3. Test calling the object out of sequence: is it unstable after? Perhaps
that indicates that your design is wrong.





HTH,
Jim
